awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II:  Harnessing Untapped Food-borne Microbial Diversity to Rationally Engineer Novel Healthy Foods
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact of this Small Business Innovation (SBIR) Phase II project is to develop a microbial starter culture that allows beverage manufacturers to produce a low-sugar, shelf-stable, nonalcoholic fermented beverage. This solves urgent challenges with existing products (e.g. kombucha, which is high in sugar and requires refrigerated distribution) and enables beverage manufacturers to replace unhealthy and artificially produced sodas ($40B+ market) with fermented and naturally produced versions. In addition, this proposal will develop underlying capacities to design new microbial communities (consortia of multiple microbes) that can work together and perform better than state-of-the-art single strains. This technology has important applications across food manufacturing, but also in other disparate verticals, such as manufacturing, agriculture, pharmaceuticals, waste remediation and more. 

The proposed project will continue the technical development and commercialize a novel starter culture that can be used to produce a shelf-stable, low sugar fermented beverages. A large biobank of food-borne microbial strains will be generated and screened utilizing next-generation metagenomic and metabolomic approaches. Novel microbial community compositions will be assembled, tested and refined from a large design space, relying on new ecological design and statistical approaches. The communities will be optimized for taste, flavor and fermentation speed and resilience. Final starter culture candidates will be advanced and validated in successively larger fermentation scales, and the ultimately output of this work will be a novel lyophilized microbial starter culture product line that will be supplied and licensed to commercial beverage manufacturers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Our SBIR Phase II project successfully developed innovative microbial technologies that enable the production of healthier food and beverage products. The research focused on discovering and optimizing beneficial microbial communities from natural food sources, with applications in both consumer beverages and pet nutrition.

Intellectual Merit: We made significant technical advances by building a comprehensive platform for discovering and characterizing beneficial microorganisms from natural food sources. We developed sophisticated screening methods to identify microbes with desired properties and created optimized microbial communities that work together to produce specific beneficial compounds. We advanced understanding of how to control and optimize these processes at commercial scale, successfully scaling production from laboratory to industrial levels while maintaining quality and consistency. This represents a substantial step forward in our ability to rationally utilize microbial communities for desirable purposes. 

Broader Impacts: This project has led to multiple commercially marketed ingredients that drive healthier consumer products. In particular, one target industry we identified through this research and commercialization efforts is in the pet nutrition industry. This work has required broader commercialization activities including sales, intellectual property work, scale-up manufacturing, and regulatory/safety.

Looking forward, the underlying technology focused on microbial communities developed under this award has applications in developing natural, functional ingredients across both human and animal nutrition. 


Last Modified: 01/29/2025
Modified by: Ravi U Sheth
